ost_step.2:

* Rolling $B^-$ would put the bee back at the origin.
* Rolling $C^+$ would result in movement along a different axis, but not necessarily on a new edge.
* Rolling $C^-$ would also result in movement along a different axis, but not necessarily on a new edge.
ost_step.3: Consider now the case when the bee lands on a corner after rolling $A^+$ once. In this case, there are three more rolls remaining, so it is impossible for the bee to traverse four distinct edges.
ost_step.4: From Step 1, we know the bee has an equal chance of landing on any one of the eight edges adjacent to the origin. Then, considering the cases of the bee landing on an edge or corner, there is a total of 8 ways out of the 16 possible outcomes (involving 4 rolls) for the bee to traverse four distinct edges.

2. Rolling $B^-$ would put the bee back at the origin.
3. Rolling $C^+$ would result in movement along a different axis, but not necessarily on a new edge.
